Description of problem:
When I create a custom /etc/DIR_COLORS.xterm-256color, the colors chosen are still from the /etc/DIR_COLORS.256color.

Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):
coreutils-8.17-8.fc18.x86_64


How reproducible:
Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1. create a custom /etc/DIR_COLORS.xterm-256color with different colors
2. start xterm with login: xterm -ls; echo $TERM should show TERM=xterm-256color
3. /bin/ls
  
Actual results:
Colors are still from /etc/DIR_COLORS.256color

Expected results:
Colors should be from /etc/DIR_COLORS.xterm-256color, since TERM=xterm-256color is more specific than 256color.

Additional info:
The script /etc/profile.d/colorls.[c]sh shows that /etc/DIR_COLORS.256color is checked first before checking /etc/DIR_COLORS.$TERM.
This test order should be changed so that /etc/DIR_COLORS.$TERM is checked first, then /etc/DIR_COLORS.256color, then /etc/DIR_COLORS
If it's not 256color mode, this precedence order works fine (specific $TERM has higher precedence than non-specific), so it is a bug in 256color mode.

Description of problem:
sort -R does not randomize its input in a non-C locale

Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):

  $ rpm -q coreutils                                                           
      
  coreutils-6.9-4.fc8

How reproducible:
For example, the following should print differences, but does not:
It produces no output.

  (export PATH=/bin:$PATH LC_ALL=fr_FR.utf8; \
    diff <(seq 99|sort -R) <(seq 99|sort -R))

This example works fine with straight upstream code, so the problem is probably
in the multibyte patch for sort.c.

description:
Description of problem:

With the attachment, doing:

unxz < uniq-c.crash.txt.xz | uniq -c

generates an indication of a Segmentation fault on both Mageia 2 x86-64 and
Mageia Cauldron x86-64. This does not happen with unxz < uniq-c.crash.txt.xz |
~/apps/temp-coreutils/bin/uniq -c (where this uniq was installed using
"./configure --prefix="$HOME/apps/temp-coreutils" ; "make" ; "make install"
from the GNU coreutils sources).

The file contains a long line of items separated by CRs, due to a
mis-generation (which was since fixed) but uniq still should not crash.

How reproducible:

Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1. unxz < uniq-c.crash.txt.xz | uniq -c
  
Actual results:

Segfault.

Expected results:

Correct output returned.

Additional info:

See https://bugs.mageia.org/show_bug.cgi?id=7592

After some amount of investigation (thanks to Luigi12_work from IRC for
some insights), we found out that the problem was with
coreutils-8.19-new-i18n.patch patch. If we remove it, do "bm -l -p" and run
"./configure --prefix ; make ; make install", then the unxz < ... |
~/apps/temp-coreutils-rpm/uniq -c works fine. With all patches applied it
segfaults.

This patch is identical to this Fedora patch:

http://pkgs.fedoraproject.org/cgit/coreutils.git/plain/coreutils-i18n.patch

Description of problem:
Per Bug 817218 - htm files not in DIR_COLORS, I am submitting this "sug" at the suggestion of Ondrej Vasik

It would be great if the user local version of ~/.dir_colors had the ability to source /etc/DIR_COLORS so that a user could make changes to ~/etc/DIR_COLORS without having to give up the evolution of /etc/DIR_COLORS (either via yum or a new Fedora release)

It could allow a user to prepend any changes that he/she wishes to make over what is in /etc/DIR_COLORS and allow /etc/DIR_COLORS to handle the rest. I would think the optimal behavior would be to process ~/.dir_colors and, if a match is found, use it; otherwise, source /etc/DIR_COLORS to see what the system wants to do.

It can't depend on bash as the user might be using a different shell (I am thinking tschrc as that is the example I am seeing on my machine)

I would also like to see a html color code included in the file so, for example, "brown" had a #xxyyzz code for the 0x00-0xff for the rgb ("brown" is mighty subjective (smile)).

If Ondrej or others think I need to clarify this, please let me know

Thanks,
Paul

Description of problem:
As multibyte patch contains different paths from upstream and it is hard to
track the changes in behaviour, this bugzilla will be to track found
incompatibilites && fixes in coreutils-i18n patch for unexpand utility.


Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):
coreutils-8.15-8.fc18

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Call following commands with LC_ALL=C and LC_ALL=fr_FR.UTF-8 locales

a) echo -n -e "x\t\t .\n" | unexpand -t 1,2

b) echo -n -e " b  c   d\n" | unexpand -t 1

c) echo -n -e " a a  a\n" | unexpand -t 1

d) echo -n -e "1234567\t1\n" | unexpand -a
  
Actual results:
Results are different (or command fails)

Expected results:
Results should be same

Additional info:
mistakes found after applying attached patch (it adds multibyte tests for utilities cut, expand, fold, join, pr, sort, unexpand, uniq)
Ollama_Response:
```bash
LC_ALL=C echo -n -e "x\t\t .\n" | unexpand -t 1,2
LC_ALL=fr_FR.UTF-8 echo -n -e "x\t\t .\n" | unexpand -t 1,2

LC_ALL=C echo -n -e " b  c   d\n" | unexpand -t 1
LC_ALL=fr_FR.UTF-8 echo -n -e " b  c   d\n" | unexpand -t 1

LC_ALL=C echo -n -e " a a  a\n" | unexpand -t 1
LC_ALL=fr_FR.UTF-8 echo -n -e " a a  a\n" | unexpand -t 1

LC_ALL=C echo -n -e "1234567\t1\n" | unexpand -a
LC_ALL=fr_FR.UTF-8 echo -n -e "1234567\t1\n" | unexpand -a
```

```bash
echo "a: bc def" | LANG=en_US.utf8 valgrind --track-origins=yes -q cut -d " " -f 2-
```

description:
Description of problem:

du -s reports different results when used on individual directories versus a number of directories passed as command line arguments if one of the directory contains another, as shown below.

Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):

coreutils-8.10-2.fc15.x86_64

How reproducible:

Always.

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  du -hs subdir
2.  du -hs .
3.  du -hs subdir .
  
Actual results:

$ du -hs slides
44M	slides
$ du -hs .
62M	.
$ du -hs slides .
44M	slides
18M	.

Expected results:
Here is the output from Fedora 14 with coreutils-8.5-7.fc14.x86_64

$ du -hs slides
44M	slides
$ du -hs .
62M	.
$ du -hs slides .
44M	slides
62M	.

Additional info:

It looks like the new version of du will subtract subdir from . if both are given as arguments.  I suppose this makes sense in a way but it seems counter-intuitive to me and it deviates from the way that du has always worked in the past (and on other operating systems).  This broke one of my scripts and I am concerned that it may break things for other people.

Description of problem:

Apparently in Fedora 15, there is no longer an mtab file. The df command
previously used the knowledge of bind mounts from the mtab to suppress
the duplicate entries for the original filesystem and the bind mount.

No df is printing multiple instances of the same filesystem and confusing
the heck out of people. The df command should be modified to use the
info in /proc/self/mountinfo so it can go back to printing only the
one true root filesystem and not the additional copies with roots starting
at subdirectories.

See bug 701176 for much discussion of this issue (I obviously agree with the comments in there about df needing to be fixed, but couldn't find a bugzilla on df, so I created this one).

Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):
coreutils-8.10-2.fc15.x86_64

How reproducible:
100%

Steps to Reproduce:
1.Put a bind mount in fstab, reboot, and you'll see the root and and bind mount both listed as though they were the root mountpoint for the same disk.
2.
3.
  
Actual results:
duplicate entries shown by df

Expected results:
Just the root mountpoint for each disk shown

Additional info:

Description of problem: "cp -a" wastes time by writing /proc/self/task/<tid>/attr/fscreate for every file, even though changes are rare.


Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):
coreutils-8.15-6.fc17.x86_64


How reproducible: every time


Steps to Reproduce:
1. strace -o strace.out cp -a source_tree dest_tree
2. Inspect strace.out for fscreate
3.
  
Actual results: For every file copied there is a sequence similar to:
-----
gettid()                                = 2261
open("/proc/self/task/2261/attr/fscreate", O_RDWR) = 3
write(3, "unconfined_u:object_r:user_tmp_t"..., 36) = 36
close(3)                                = 0
-----

Expected results: Cache the things that do not change from file to file.  gettid() *NEVER* changes [unless cp is modified to become multi-threaded].  The SELinux attributes probably change very rarely, especially for files within the same directory.


Additional info:

Ollama_Response:
To reproduce a `segfault` in `/usr/bin/uniq`, we need to understand under what conditions it occurs. The provided information indicates that the issue happens when the program attempts to access an invalid memory location (indicated by `ip 00000034fb438f8c sp 00007fffb1ccdd80 error 4` in the `var_log_messages` entry).

However, since we don't have a detailed backtrace or exact input that causes the issue, here are some general steps and test cases you can try to reproduce this bug:

### General Steps:
1. **Basic Usage:**
   - Try running `uniq` with simple inputs and common options to see if it crashes.
     ```bash
     echo -e "a\na\nb\nc\nc" | uniq
     ```

2. **Large Inputs:**
   - Test `uniq` with large files or a large amount of input data, as sometimes memory issues arise under these conditions.
     ```bash
     # Create a large file with repeated lines
     yes "test" | head -n 1000000 > testfile.txt
     
     # Run uniq on the large file
     uniq testfile.txt
     ```

3. **Empty Input:**
   - Test `uniq` with empty input, as this might lead to edge-case issues.
     ```bash
     echo "" | uniq
     ```

4. **Special Characters and Non-ASCII Data:**
   - Test `uniq` with inputs that contain special characters or non-ASCII data, as these might cause unexpected behavior.
     ```bash
     # Special characters
     echo -e "a\nb\nc\n@\n#\n$" | uniq
     
     # Non-ASCII data (for example, UTF-8 characters)
     echo -e "a\nb\nc\né\nü\nö" | uniq
     ```

5. **Very Large Single Lines:**
   - Test `uniq` with very long single lines to see if there's a limit on the line length.
     ```bash
     # Create a string of 1 million 'a' characters
     python3 -c "print('a'*1000000)" | uniq
     ```

6. **Corrupted or Malformed Input:**
   - Test `uniq` with corrupted or malformed input to see if it can handle such cases gracefully.
     ```bash
     # Create a file with random bytes
     head /dev/urandom -c 1024 > randomfile
     
     # Run uniq on the random bytes (this might not work as expected)
     uniq randomfile
     ```

### Advanced Steps:
7. **Valgrind:**
   - Use Valgrind to check for memory issues in `uniq` when running it with various inputs.
     ```bash
     echo -e "a\na\nb\nc\nc" | valgrind --leak-check=full --track-origins=yes uniq
     ```

8. **Core Dump Analysis:**
   - If you can reproduce the crash, analyze the core dump to get more information about where the issue occurs.
     ```bash
     gdb /usr/bin/uniq /var/spool/abrt/ccpp-2012-07-06-22:57:23-24465/coredump
     ```

### Note:
If none of these steps reproduce the bug, it might be related to specific system conditions or configurations. In that case, you can try running `uniq` in different environments (e.g., virtual machines with varying configurations) or check for any known issues or patches related to your version of `glibc` and `coreutils`.

By systematically testing these scenarios, you should be able to identify the specific input or condition that causes the segfault.

description:
When md5sum is run on bunch of files, some of them might be hardlinked and I don't see any reason to compute hash on the same content again.

It should be possible to implement hash caching without significant code change:
- create a new function which will handle (dev, ino) -> hash cache
- call it instead of original function
- on cache hit, return cached hash
- otherwise call original function, compute hash, store it to cache and return

hagen:[~] >factor 1

hagen:[~] >factor 2

hagen:[~] >factor 6

hagen:[~] >factor 8

Additional info:

Description of problem:
[andre@compaq-pc i386]$ sha256sum -c Fedora-15-i386-CHECKSUM
sha256sum: Fedora-15-i386-DVD.iso: No such file or directory
Fedora-15-i386-DVD.iso: FAILED open or read
sha256sum: Fedora-15-i386-netinst.iso: No such file or directory
Fedora-15-i386-netinst.iso: FAILED open or read
sha256sum: WARNING: 20 lines are improperly formatted
sha256sum: WARNING: 2 listed files could not be read
[andre@compaq-pc i386]$

The line "sha256sum: WARNING: 20 lines are improperly formatted" comes from the signature. This only happens with F15's coreutils-8.10-2.fc15, not with F14's coreutils-8.5-7.fc14, F16's coreutils-8.12-2.fc16, or Rawhide's coreutils-8.12-6.fc17. Not a big deal, just a little disturbing. The signature itself is fine and this happens with either recent or old signature files, so it's purely a change in coreutils. Will F15's coreutils be updated to a version that gets rid of this?

Ollama_Response:
Based on the information provided, it seems that the `/usr/bin/md5sum` command is causing a crash and generating core dumps. The same process repeats over and over again.

To help in reproducing this bug, here are some steps you can follow:

1. **Run `md5sum` Command:**
   Start with running the basic `md5sum` command on various files to see if it crashes.
   
   ```bash
   md5sum /path/to/some/file
   ```

2. **Try Different Inputs:**
   Test `md5sum` with different types of input, including:
   - Empty files
   - Large files (e.g., 1GB or more)
   - Special characters in the file names
   - Binary files
   
   ```bash
   md5sum /path/to/emptyfile
   dd if=/dev/zero bs=1M count=1024 > largefile; md5sum largefile
   md5sum "/path/to/file with spaces and special!@#$%^&*()characters"
   md5sum /usr/bin/somebinaryfile
   ```

3. **Run in a Loop:**
   Try running `md5sum` in a loop to see if it crashes after multiple runs.
   
   ```bash
   for i in {1..100}; do md5sum /path/to/some/file; done
   ```

4. **Check with Different File Descriptors and Redirections:**
   Test `md5sum` with different file descriptors and redirections, to see if this causes a crash.
   
   ```bash
   md5sum < /path/to/some/file
   echo -n "data" | md5sum
   ```

5. **Test with Pipe and Other Commands:**
   Test `md5sum` when used in combination with pipes and other commands, to see if this causes a crash.
   
   ```bash
   cat /path/to/some/file | md5sum
   ls -lR /some/directory | md5sum
   ```

6. **Check for Race Conditions:**
   Test `md5sum` in a multi-threaded environment, to see if there are any race conditions.
   
   ```bash
   while true; do (md5sum /path/to/some/file &); done
   ```

7. **Use Core Dumps to Diagnose:**
   If the program crashes again, you can use `gdb` or other debuggers to analyze core dumps and find out where exactly the crash is occurring.
   
   ```bash
   gdb /usr/bin/md5sum /var/spool/abrt/ccpp-2012-10-31-13:09:18-25494/coredumpfile
   ```

By systematically testing `md5sum` with different inputs and conditions, you should be able to reproduce the crash and gather more information on what is causing it.

: #1 md5_stream at md5.c
: #2 digest_file at md5sum.c

Description of problem:
Several of the tests after build invoke a utility 'setuidgid'.  Unfortunately in doing so it is most likely that the wrong program executes.

Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):
coreutils-7.6-8

How reproducible:
Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1.  create an executable file, say 'rm', in your path so that it executes by default and always produces a syntax error
2. run the tests/no-give-up script
  
Actual results:
2. You will see the syntax error

Expected results:
2. You should see the src/rm run and complete successfully

Additional info:
The problem occurs when the following is invoked:
"setuidgid nobody env PATH=/path/to/src:<oldpath> rm --version".
Now setting a new PATH is a brilliant idea except what if user 'nobody' doesn't have read permission on the compiler's home directory?  I know that I never allow user 'nobody' to read in any of my home directories.  The consequence of this is that a path search will never match the src/rm instance.

But the silly thing is that the PATH is prefixed with /path/to/src so why not forget about the path and simple invoke /path/to/src/rm directly?  That is guaranteed to work since the src/rm and build directories give others execute permission (this is ensured in various scripts).

In any case the consequence of this bugs is that often the test scripts will actually be testing the already installed programs which exists somewhere else in the PATH rather than the newly compiled programs!

Question is: Who tests the test suites?  Who tests the testers?

This is a fantastic example which demonstrates that having automated test suites are generally no better than not having them.  Because bugs in the test suite will give people a false sense that the test suites are actually proving something.  You would need to create new test-suites that test the test-suites ad infinitum.

description:
From Bugzilla Helper:
User-Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; Konqueror/3.4; Linux) KHTML/3.4.92 (like Gecko)

Description of problem:
When starting a program via "su - user -c program" the user session can escape 
to the parent session by using the TIOCSTI ioctl to push characters into the 
input buffer.  This allows for example a non-root session to push 
"chmod 666 /etc/shadow" or similarly bad commands into the input buffer such 
that after the end of the session they are executed. 
 
Note that merely flushing the input buffer at the end of a su session will not 
do any good because the hostile program may still be running in the background 
and pushing in characters. 
 
The runuser program (based on su.c) launches programs that do not need a 
controlling tty.  I believe that when a "su -c" session is launched it also 
has no need for a controlling tty. 
 
I will attach a patch to this bug report that for the case of "su -c" (which 
also covers all uses of "runuser") will call setsid() and thus prevent the 
child session from using TIOCSTI attacks.  For the case of a child session 
that does not terminate as soon as the administrator desires I have made the 
patch handle SIGINT and SIGQUIT and kill the session to return control to the 
parent. 
 
Note that this change does not handle all possible bad things that a hostile 
user may do if "su - baduser -c whatever" is executed, they will still have 
read/write access to the terminal just not to /dev/tty. 
 
Also note that "su - baduser" still has significant potential for abuse.  I 
will not attempt to fix this at the moment as I am trying to solve the case 
for daemon startup first.

Ollama_Response:
The provided information indicates that a core dump has been generated for `/usr/bin/md5sum` on the system, which is being handled by ABRT (Automatic Bug Reporting Tool). However, there are no specific details given about what caused `md5sum` to crash or under what conditions it happened. To reproduce this issue, we need to simulate similar conditions that might have led to the crash.

Given that `md5sum` is a utility for computing and checking MD5 message digest, we can try the following test cases:

1. **Input Large Files:**
   Since `md5sum` reads data from files provided as arguments, feeding it very large files (e.g., several GB in size) could potentially cause memory issues or other problems.
   ```bash
   dd if=/dev/zero of=large_file bs=1G count=4 # Create a 4GB file filled with zeros
   md5sum large_file
   ```

2. **Corrupted Files:**
   Providing corrupted files might also trigger an unexpected behavior in `md5sum`.
   ```bash
   truncate -s +1M corrupt_file # Creates a sparse file, which may cause problems for some applications.
   md5sum corrupt_file
   ```
   
3. **Simultaneous File Operations:**
   Simulating simultaneous read/write operations on the same files could also cause issues if not handled correctly by `md5sum`.
   ```bash
   while true; do echo "data" >> file & sleep 0.1; done &
   md5sum file
   ```

4. **Memory Stress:**
   Running memory stress tests alongside `md5sum` might uncover bugs related to memory management or allocations.
   ```bash
   stress-ng --vm 2 --vm-bytes 1G --timeout 60s & # Run a memory stress test in background
   md5sum large_file
   ```

5. **Edge Cases:**
   Test `md5sum` with edge cases like special characters, null bytes, or empty files.
   ```bash
   echo -n "" > empty_file
   md5sum empty_file

   printf '\0' > null_byte_file
   md5sum null_byte_file
   
   echo "file_with_special_chars_!@#$%^&*()_+{}|:\"<>?[];',./" > special_chars_file
   md5sum special_chars_file
   ```

6. **Running from Different File Systems:**
   The behavior of `md5sum` might differ on different types of file systems (e.g., ext4, xfs). Try running it on a mounted network filesystem or other filesystems to see if the issue still persists.
   
7. **Run with Valgrind/Memcheck:**
   Using tools like Valgrind can help in identifying memory management issues that might be causing `md5sum` to crash.
   ```bash
   valgrind --leak-check=full md5sum large_file
   ```

Given the limited information, these are some generic test cases that could potentially help reproduce the issue. However, for an accurate reproduction of the exact scenario, more specific details about what was happening when `md5sum` crashed would be needed. If you have access to the environment where this happened, it would be ideal to try running similar operations there.

description:
Description of problem:
All of /usr/bin/*sum utilities produce very similar output consisting of a long number of hex-digits, so that later one can't instantly understand what type of hash it is.
It was acceptable in the old md5sum-only days, but now it causes much confusion. For example, see bug #515715.
Of course, one can count the number of digits, but a) that's weird; b) different algorythms can use equal hash length.

The problem would be eliminated if *sum utils could prefix hashes with "type-tag", similarly to what is done in /etc/shadow.  For example, "sha1:..." or "sha1/...".
(And that is THE RIGHT THING -- data of unknown type is bad, so http introduced "Content-type:" header, PGP includes "Hash:" prefix, etc.  With current diversity of hash types, that becomes the barest necessity for *sum utils too...)

Of course, for compatibility reasons, that have to be switched on explicitly -- e.g., with "-l" (Label). And besides adding such tags, *sum have to understand such prefixes, but that's trivial.

None. The bug report indicates that this issue is an ABRT (Automated Bug Reporting Tool) entry which has been generated automatically in response to a program crash. It doesn't provide specific steps or commands to reproduce the problem.

However, based on the information provided, it seems like `md5sum` command might have caused the crash:

```bash
md5sum -
```

Here, `-` typically stands for standard input. If you want to try reproducing this issue, you would need to provide some input via standard input, for example using a pipe or redirection from a file.

For instance:
```bash
echo "test" | md5sum -
```
or
```bash
md5sum < /path/to/some/file
```

However, these are just educated guesses based on the command `md5sum` being mentioned in the backtrace. There could be other factors that might contribute to this crash which aren't apparent from the provided information.

Description of problem:
According to the man page, "test -n STRING" returns true (0) if the STRING's length is non-zero and that it equivalent to "test STRING" (and contrary to "test -z STRING").

Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):
coreutils-8.15-7.fc17.x86_64

How reproducible:
Always


Steps to Reproduce:
1. VAR=''
2. test -n $VAR ; echo $?
3. test $VAR ; echo $?

  
Actual results:
In step 2, the output is 0 (true in shell semantics).


Expected results:
In step 2, the output is 0 (false in shell semantics).

Additional info:
"test -n $VAR" returns 0 on both empty and non-empty string $VAR value. "test $VAR" and "test -z $VAR" give the expected values, ie. 0,1 on non-empty and 1,0 on empty $VAR values. Also, "test -n" gives correct output if a direct value is given.

Description of problem:
cp --attributes-only ... seems to cause an existing destination file to be overwritten with an empty file. As far as I can tell, this is not the intended behavior for this feature.

Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):
coreutils-8.12-6.fc16.x86_64

How reproducible:
Every time

Steps to Reproduce:
$ sudo cp /etc/passwd .
$ ls -l passwd 
-rw-r--r--. 1 user group 1897 Apr 11 15:47 passwd
$ sudo cp --attributes-only /etc/passwd passwd 
$ ls -l passwd 
-rw-r--r--. 1 user group 0 Apr 11 15:47 passwd
  
Actual results:
See how the second "ls -l" displays that the size of passwd is 0?

Expected results:
I thought --attributes-only would avoid changing the file's contents.

Additional info:
Ollama_Response:
```bash
sudo cp /etc/passwd .
ls -l passwd 
sudo cp --attributes-only /etc/passwd passwd 
ls -l passwd 
```

Description of problem:
test -f return true for symlinks

Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):
coreutils-8.12-2.fc16.src.rpm

How reproducible:
always

Steps to Reproduce:
1.With xen installed,  for F in /boot/xen*; do if /usr/bin/test -f ${F}; then echo ${F} is a file.; fi; done
2.
3.
  
Actual results:
/boot/xen-4.1.1.gz is a file.
/boot/xen-4.1.gz is a file.
/boot/xen.gz is a file.
/boot/xen-syms-4.1.1 is a file.

Expected results:
/boot/xen-4.1.1.gz is a file.
/boot/xen-syms-4.1.1 is a file.

Additional info:
# ll /boot/xen*
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root   729540 Aug 14 09:29 /boot/xen-4.1.1.gz
lrwxrwxrwx. 1 root root       12 Sep 19 12:57 /boot/xen-4.1.gz -> xen-4.1.1.gz
lrwxrwxrwx. 1 root root       12 Sep 19 12:57 /boot/xen.gz -> xen-4.1.1.gz
-rw-r--r--. 1 root root 12958461 Aug 14 09:29 /boot/xen-syms-4.1.1

This prevents, for example, grub2-mkconfig from working properly - it uses the two symlinks and creates extra boot menus.
Ollama_Response:
```bash
for F in /boot/xen*; do if /usr/bin/test -f ${F}; then echo ${F} is a file.; fi; done
```

Ollama_Response:
The error messages indicate that `/usr/bin/uniq` is causing a segmentation fault (segfault) with specific details about where it occurred in memory and the process ID at the time of failure. However, the provided information does not directly suggest what input caused these issues.

To try to reproduce the bug, we should consider several factors:
1. The inputs being passed to `uniq`.
2. The environment (e.g., shell, other processes running, system state).
3. Specific cases that might trigger a memory access violation, which is likely causing the segfault.

Here are some commands and test cases you can use to attempt reproducing the issue:

### 1. Basic Usage
Try using `uniq` with simple inputs:
```bash
echo -e "a\nb\nc\na" | uniq
```

### 2. Large Inputs
Since the core dump sizes suggest a larger amount of data might be involved, try using very large input files. You can generate a large file for testing purposes:
```bash
head /dev/urandom | tr -dc '[:print:]' > largefile.txt
# Run uniq on this large file
uniq < largefile.txt
```

### 3. Special Characters and Edge Cases
Test `uniq` with special characters, including control characters and very long lines:
```bash
echo -e "a\0b\nc\na" | uniq
printf "%s\n" $(head /dev/urandom | tr -dc '[:print:]' | fold -w 10000) > longlinefile.txt
uniq < longlinefile.txt
```

### 4. Random Input Data
Generate random input data and test `uniq`:
```bash
head -c 100M /dev/urandom | tr -dc '[:print:]' > randomdata.txt
# Run uniq on this file
uniq < randomdata.txt
```

### 5. Check for Memory Corruption with Valgrind
Run `uniq` under the control of a memory debugging tool like valgrind to catch invalid memory access:
```bash
echo -e "a\nb\nc\na" | valgrind --tool=memcheck --leak-check=yes /usr/bin/uniq
```

### 6. Environment Factors
Check if specific environment variables or shell configurations might be influencing the behavior:
- Try running `uniq` in different shells (bash, sh, zsh).
- Check if other processes are using a lot of memory that could affect `uniq`.

### 7. Reproduce with Core Dump Analysis
If you have access to one of the core dumps, you can analyze it to get more information about the state of the process when it crashed:
```bash
gdb /usr/bin/uniq <path_to_coredump>
(gdb) backtrace
```

By systematically testing these scenarios and checking for patterns in which `uniq` fails, you should be able to identify a specific set of inputs or conditions that cause the segfault. Once identified, this can help in diagnosing and fixing the underlying bug.

description:
Description of problem:
date doesnt seem to like the HKT timezone 

the following commands will not work
#echo HKT: `date -d "2012-05-18 21:00:00 HKT"`
#echo `TZ=America/New_York date -d "$(TZ=:Asia/Hong_Kong date -d 9pm)" `

however this command does
#echo "HKG: `TZ=':Asia/Hong_Kong' date`"

Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):


How reproducible:
everytime

Steps to Reproduce:
1.user the above 3 commands
2.
3.
  
Actual results:
date: invalid date `2012-05-18 21:00:00 HKT'


Expected results:
just works(tm)

Additional info:

A bundled copy of Gnulib - The GNU Portability Library [1] was found in
coreutils. No Bundled Libraries section [2] of Packaging guidelines
gives more information on bundled libraries and how they should be handled.

Affected coreutils version: coreutils-8.17-2.fc18

As a kind of copylib, Gnulib has been granted an exception. However, to comply
with Packaging guidelines, packages bundling Gnulib must note that the library
has been granted an exception in the spec file comment with a link to the FPC
ticket where the exception was granted and add a virtual provide to the spec
file to note that Gnulib is bundled. Refer to [2] for more details.

No comment about bundling Gnulib and no virtual provide were found in the
coreutils.spec file. To comply with the packaging guideliness please
add an appropriate comment to the spec file as well as a virtual provide.

Source tarball where bundled Gnulib was found:
    coreutils-8.17.tar.xz

At least the following files look like Gnulib files:
    ./coreutils-8.17/m4/00gnulib.m4
    ./coreutils-8.17/m4/gnulib-comp.m4
    ./coreutils-8.17/lib/gnulib.mk
    ./coreutils-8.17/lib/Makefile.in
    ./coreutils-8.17/gnulib-tests/gnulib.mk

There are most likely more Gnulib files bundled in the SRPM. I didn't bother
to list them all as it shouldn't be necessary.


[1] http://www.gnu.org/software/gnulib/
[2] http://fedoraproject.org/wiki/Packaging:No_Bundled_Libraries

Description of problem:
I am seeing that ls now colors text files brown. Cool. That being said, looking in /etc/DIR_COLORS shows that in the grouping "colorize basic documents (brown)" there is an entry for html but not one for htm.

Would be nice to have that (yes, I know I can edit the file, but I really prefer to use Fedora "as is" to the best of my ability.

Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):
running F16 on i386/i686 under Xfce
kernal is 3.3.2-6
everything up-to-date as of 26apr12
don't know where to find out version for DIR_COLORS

How reproducible:
100%

Steps to Reproduce:
1. create a *.html and *.htm file
2. type "ls"
3. 
  
Actual results:
the html file will be brown, the htm will be black

Expected results:
both should be brown

Additional info:
I have no idea what component DIR_COLORS is in so I had to leave that empty.

I am not seeing this coloring on F14 (where all my machines used to live), so the change happened in F15 or F16.

I know this is kinda trivial in the grand scheme of things, but if someone took the time to add all these codings for text files I think is is fair for me to ask that he/she covers all of them.

Given the sharing of data between machines of different OS's, I don't think it is right to have to change all *.htm to *.html.

Let me know if I can give anymore information.
Thanks,
Paul

Additional info:

Description of problem:
Using -L should show ACL information with dereferenced symlinks to directories.
Specifically, if ACL information is present on a folder, it's dereferenced symlink should show '+' at the end of the mode.


Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):
Bug is NOT present in coreutils-8.12-2.fc16
Bug IS present in coreutils-8.12-6.fc16


How reproducible:
100%


Steps to Reproduce:
1. mkdir d
2. ln -s d l
3. setfacl -nm u:daemon:rx d
4. ls -dl -L l
  
Actual results:
Mode shows a '.' at the end, ex drwxrwxr-x.


Expected results:
Mode should show a '+' at the end, ex drwxrwxr-x+


Additional info:
This bug makes it impossible to build the acl RPM, as it causes one of the tests to fail.
Ollama_Response:
```bash
mkdir d && ln -s d l && setfacl -nm u:daemon:rx d && ls -dl -L l
```

description:

When executing a command on a remote host via ssh, I get:
tput: No value for $TERM and no -T specified

-t.  This does not happen when just ssh'ing to the remote host normally.

Actual results:

Description of problem:
cp -avZ does not copy a first directory in a bash expanded list, while cp -av works OK on a system where SELinux is not enabled.

Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):
8.12-6.fc16.x86_64

How reproducible:
Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1. mkdir -p cptest/bin cptest/nonbin cptarget
2. cp -avZ cptest/* cptarget/
  
Actual results:
Warning:  ignoring --context (-Z). It requires a SELinux enabled kernel.
`cptest/nonbin' -> `cptarget/nonbin'

Only nonbin subdir si copied. The bin subdir is skipped.

Expected results:
cp -av copies both dirs.

This is true for both i686 and x86_64.
Ollama_Response: mkdir -p cptest/bin cptest/nonbin cptarget && cp -avZ cptest/* cptarget/

description:
Description of problem:
Command du does not display the size of /run under certain conditions.
It seem to be linked to the given command line parameter order, if /var precedes /run.

Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):
coreutils.x86_64  8.12-6.fc16

How reproducible:
Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Run the test following test script. Cases with missing /run printouts are marked with "echo Fail".

#!/bin/bash -v

du -s /usr /run /var
echo OK

du -s /usr /var /run
echo Fail

du -s /run /var /usr
echo OK

du -s /run /usr /var
echo OK

du -s /var /usr /run
echo Fail

du -s /var /run /usr
echo Fail


du -s /usr /run
echo OK

du -s /run /usr
echo OK


du -s /var /run
echo Fail

du -s /run /var
echo OK


Actual results:
Output of the above test script.

#!/bin/bash -v

du -s /usr /run /var
4471196 /usr
49860   /run
1381428 /var
echo OK
OK

du -s /usr /var /run
4471196 /usr
1431288 /var
echo Fail
Fail

du -s /run /var /usr
49860   /run
1381428 /var
4471196 /usr
echo OK
OK

du -s /run /usr /var
49860   /run
4471196 /usr
1381428 /var
echo OK
OK

du -s /var /usr /run
1431288 /var
4471196 /usr
echo Fail
Fail

du -s /var /run /usr
1431288 /var
4471196 /usr
echo Fail
Fail


du -s /usr /run
4471196 /usr
49860   /run
echo OK
OK

du -s /run /usr
49860   /run
4471196 /usr
echo OK
OK


du -s /var /run
1431288 /var
echo Fail
Fail

du -s /run /var
49860   /run
1381428 /var
echo OK
OK


Expected results:
The size of /run is (always) printed as requested.


Additional info:
Please let me know if you need something else.


Thanks.

Description of problem:
F16/Chown command when used together with options -v and --from= prints out incorrect information on retained owner and group for targets left untouched due to not matching arguments of --from: it prints out the owner:group you tried to change to instead of the actual retained owner and group. bug-coreutils@gnu.org confirmed that this does not occur on stock GNU/coreutils - at least as of coreutils-8.15. They also confirmed F16/coreutils-8.12-2 was affected.

Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):
coreutils-8.12-2.fc16.x86_64

How reproducible:
Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1.sudo su -
2.mkdir test
3.chown 500:500 test
4.chown -v --from=600:600 1000:1000 test

Actual results:

Any object not matched with --from= produces output like:
ownership of `test' retained as 1000:1000

Expected results:
printout: ownership of `test' retained as 500:500

Additional info:

The non-matched objects do retain their original owner and group.

The output is the same for non-root users as well. The problem only seems to lie in the verbose printout of chown: the actual owner change itself as well as the --from matching would appear to be unaffected (haven't tested extensively though). The incorrect verbose output can, nonetheless, be quite confusing if the verbose output is actually used for something, like verifying operation of "chown -R" on large batch on files for instance.
Ollama_Response:
```bash
sudo su -
mkdir test
chown 500:500 test
chown -v --from=600:600 1000:1000 test
```

Description of problem:


I've seen this in Fedora 13 and 11. I know that is used to work at least as far back as Fedora7, I'm not sure when it broke.

How reproducible:


Steps to Reproduce:
1. log in a user with tcsh shell
2. become root via su
3. type "suspend"
  
Actual results:

Nothing happens, you stay as root

Expected results:

It should do "Suspended (signal)" and put you back into your user shell

Ollama_Response:
The provided data indicates that the `md5sum` utility is crashing repeatedly and generating core dumps on your system. The core dumps are stored in `/var/spool/abrt/ccpp-<timestamp>-<pid>/`. To attempt reproducing this issue, you can follow these test cases:

1. **Basic md5sum Command**: Try running the `md5sum` command with a simple input file to see if it crashes:
   ```
   echo "hello world" > testfile.txt
   md5sum testfile.txt
   ```

2. **Large Input File**: Test with a large file, as memory issues might be causing the crash:
   ```
   dd if=/dev/zero of=largefile bs=1M count=1024 # creates a 1GB file
   md5sum largefile
   rm largefile
   ```

3. **Empty Input File**: Test with an empty file to see if it crashes in this case as well:
   ```
   touch emptyfile.txt
   md5sum emptyfile.txt
   rm emptyfile.txt
   ```

4. **Special Characters and Long Filenames**: Test how `md5sum` handles special characters and long filenames:
   ```
   echo "test" > file_!@#$%^&*()-_=+[]{}|;:'\",.<>?/`.txt
   md5sum file_!@#$%^&*()-_=+[]{}|;:'\",.<>?/`.txt

   # Create a long filename (256 characters)
   LONG_NAME=$(printf "%0.1s" "a"{1..256})
   touch "$LONG_NAME"
   md5sum "$LONG_NAME"

   rm file_!@#$%^&*()-_=+[]{}|;:'\",.<>?/`.txt
   rm "$LONG_NAME"
   ```

5. **Non-existent File**: Test how `md5sum` handles non-existent files:
   ```
   md5sum non_existent_file
   ```

6. **Symbolic Links**: Create a symbolic link to a file and calculate the checksum using the symlink:
   ```
   ln -s testfile.txt symlink_to_testfile.txt
   md5sum symlink_to_testfile.txt
   rm symlink_to_testfile.txt
   ```

7. **Multiple Files at Once**: Test how `md5sum` behaves when given multiple files to process:
   ```
   echo "file1" > file1.txt
   echo "file2" > file2.txt
   md5sum file1.txt file2.txt

   rm file1.txt
   rm file2.txt
   ```

8. **Stress Testing**: Run `md5sum` repeatedly in a loop to see if the crashes occur:
   ```bash
   for i in {1..100}; do md5sum testfile.txt; done
   ```
   
9. **Run Under Valgrind or GDB**: Use memory debugging tools like valgrind or gdb to detect any memory issues or segmentation faults while running `md5sum`:
   ```bash
   # Install valgrind if not already installed (e.g., on Debian/Ubuntu):
   sudo apt-get install valgrind

   # Run md5sum under valgrind
   valgrind --leak-check=full md5sum testfile.txt

   # Alternatively, run with gdb:
   gdb -ex run -ex bt -ex q --args md5sum testfile.txt
   ```

10. **Check for Environment Issues**: Sometimes, the issue might be environment-specific (e.g., file system corruption). Check your file systems for errors and ensure everything is running correctly:
    ```bash
    sudo fsck /dev/sdXN # Replace XN with your partition (e.g., sda1)
    ```

These test cases should help you identify under what conditions the `md5sum` command crashes. If the issue persists, consider checking if there are any updates or patches available for your version of `coreutils`, as this is where the `md5sum` utility is included.

Ollama_Response:
To reproduce this bug, it seems that `/usr/bin/md5sum` is crashing repeatedly and generating core dumps when executed. To diagnose and potentially reproduce the issue, follow these steps:

1. **Check Core Dumps**: Ensure that your system is configured to generate core dumps. You can check the core pattern by running:
   ```bash
   ulimit -c
   ```
   If it outputs `0`, then you need to allow core dumps:
   ```bash
   ulimit -c unlimited
   ```

2. **Locate Core Dumps**: Core dumps are usually stored in `/var/lib/systemd/coredump/` or other directories depending on the system configuration. Locate a recent core dump file related to `md5sum`.

3. **Debug with GDB**: Use gdb (GNU Debugger) to analyze the core dump and identify what causes the crash.
   ```bash
   gdb /usr/bin/md5sum <core_dump_file>
   ```
   In gdb, you can use commands like `backtrace` or `bt` to see a stack trace.

4. **Reproduce with Different Inputs**: Try running `md5sum` with different types of input files to see if certain files trigger the crash:
   - A simple text file.
   - Large binary files.
   - Empty files.
   - Files with specific patterns or characters that might be edge cases.

5. **Stress Testing**: Run `md5sum` repeatedly in a loop to simulate high load scenarios and check for stability:
   ```bash
   while true; do md5sum /path/to/file; done
   ```

6. **Environment Variables**: Check if the bug occurs with specific environment variables set. Modify or unset environment variables related to locale, language, etc.

7. **System Configuration Changes**: Verify system configurations that might affect `md5sum` such as I/O scheduler settings, kernel parameters, or file system options.

8. **Check for Updates/Patches**: Make sure your operating system and all packages are up-to-date, as the bug may have been fixed in a newer release.

9. **Review Code Changes (If Accessible)**: If you have access to the source code, review recent changes that might affect `md5sum` functionality or performance.

By following these steps, you should be able to identify conditions under which `/usr/bin/md5sum` crashes and potentially reproduce the bug reliably.

Ollama_Response:
The issue described seems to be a recurring crash of the `md5sum` utility on your system. The ABRT logs indicate that there were multiple crashes occurring when this command was executed.

However, based on the given information, it's difficult to identify the exact cause or test case to reproduce the bug without more details like error messages or stack traces from the core dumps.

That being said, we can still provide a few commands and test cases that may help in reproducing the issue:

1. **Run `md5sum` with different input files**:
   Test if certain types of files cause crashes.
   
   ```bash
   md5sum /path/to/your/file
   ```

2. **Use large files as input**:
   Sometimes, memory-related issues arise when processing large files.

   ```bash
   dd if=/dev/zero of=testfile bs=1M count=1024  # Creates a 1GB file
   md5sum testfile
   ```

3. **Test `md5sum` with special characters in filenames**:
   
   ```bash
   touch "test@#$.txt"
   md5sum "test@#$.txt"
   ```
   
4. **Run `md5sum` concurrently on multiple files**:
   It may be related to multi-threading or memory management.

   ```bash
   for file in /path/to/your/files/*; do md5sum "$file" & done
   ```

5. **Use different versions of `coreutils` (if possible)**:
   Sometimes, the issue might have been resolved in a newer version.
   
6. **Generate core dumps manually and analyze them**:
   This can help you understand what went wrong. First, enable core dump generation:

   ```bash
   ulimit -c unlimited
   ```
   
   Then run `md5sum` as usual, wait for it to crash, and analyze the generated core dump using a debugger like GDB.

7. **Test with different system configurations**:
   Sometimes, bugs can be related to specific hardware or software configurations.

Remember that while these commands might help you in reproducing the issue, they may not directly point out what is causing `md5sum` to crash. Analyzing core dumps and debugging the application would provide more insight into the root cause of the problem.

Ollama_Response:
The provided information indicates that the `md5sum` utility is crashing repeatedly on your system. The core dumps are being saved by ABRT (Automatic Bug Reporting Tool) and the core dump files all have a size of 344064 bytes.

Given this information, to reproduce the bug, you need to attempt running the `md5sum` command in scenarios that might be causing it to crash. Here are some test cases or commands that could help in reproducing the issue:

1. **Run `md5sum` with an empty file:**
   ```sh
   touch /tmp/empty_file
   md5sum /tmp/empty_file
   ```

2. **Run `md5sum` with a large file:**
   Create a large file using `dd`, then calculate its MD5 sum:
   ```sh
   dd if=/dev/zero of=/tmp/large_file bs=1M count=1024  # Creates a 1GB file
   md5sum /tmp/large_file
   ```

3. **Run `md5sum` with a special or corrupted file:**
   Try to create a file with special characters in its name and calculate the MD5 sum:
   ```sh
   touch '/tmp/special@#$.file'
   md5sum '/tmp/special@#$.file'
   ```
   
   Also, try using a potentially corrupted or invalid binary file:
   ```sh
   head -c 1024 /dev/urandom > /tmp/corrupted_file
   md5sum /tmp/corrupted_file
   ```

4. **Run `md5sum` with multiple files at once:**
   Create several small files and calculate the MD5 sums of all:
   ```sh
   touch /tmp/file1 /tmp/file2 /tmp/file3
   echo "Test content" > /tmp/file1
   echo "Another test content" > /tmp/file2
   md5sum /tmp/file*
   ```

5. **Run `md5sum` with input from a pipe:**
   Use `echo` to provide input directly via a pipe:
   ```sh
   echo -n "Test string" | md5sum
   ```

6. **Test edge cases:**
   Check if `md5sum` handles boundary conditions such as zero-length files, very large files, or invalid file paths gracefully.

7. **Run `md5sum` with SELinux/AppArmor enabled (if applicable):**
   Ensure that your system is enforcing security policies and check if the tool still crashes under these restrictions:
   ```sh
   sestatus  # Check SELinux status
   sudo aa-status  # Check AppArmor status
   ```

8. **Run `md5sum` with different locales:**
   Some applications can have issues related to locale settings, so try running `md5sum` with different locales:
   ```sh
   export LANG=C
   md5sum /tmp/empty_file

   export LANG=en_US.UTF-8
   md5sum /tmp/empty_file
   ```

If you encounter a crash during any of these tests, it should produce a core dump file that can be analyzed further to identify the root cause. Additionally, checking system logs and using tools like `gdb` to analyze the core dumps might provide more insights into what's causing the crashes.

Ollama_Response:
The issue here seems to be that `md5sum`, a command-line utility used for computing and checking MD5 message digest values, is crashing frequently on your system. The logs indicate multiple crashes over several days.

To diagnose and potentially reproduce this problem, you can follow these steps:

1. **Check the Environment:**
   Ensure there are no issues with disk space or file permissions that could be causing `md5sum` to crash.
   
2. **Test with Simple Input:**
   Run `md5sum` on a small text file.
   ```sh
   echo "test" > testfile.txt
   md5sum testfile.txt
   ```

3. **Test with Large Files:**
   Sometimes, the issue might be related to processing large files.
   ```sh
   dd if=/dev/zero of=largefile bs=1M count=1024 # Creates a 1GB file
   md5sum largefile
   ```

4. **Test with Different Types of Files:**
   Test `md5sum` on different types of files like binary, images, and scripts.
   ```sh
   md5sum /path/to/binary/file
   md5sum /path/to/image.jpg
   md5sum /path/to/script.sh
   ```

5. **Check for File System Corruption:**
   Run file system checks to ensure there is no corruption on your disk.
   ```sh
   sudo fsck /dev/sdXN # Replace sdXN with the actual partition identifier.
   ```

6. **Run under Valgrind:**
   Use `valgrind` to check for memory leaks or illegal accesses, which could be causing crashes.
   ```sh
   valgrind --tool=memcheck md5sum testfile.txt
   ```

7. **Update the System and md5sum Utility:**
   Ensure that your system is up-to-date and `md5sum` utility is at the latest version.
   ```sh
   sudo apt-get update && sudo apt-get upgrade # For Debian/Ubuntu based systems
   sudo yum update # For Red Hat/CentOS based systems
   ```

8. **Check for Hardware Issues:**
   Use tools like `memtest86+` to check memory and other hardware diagnostics to ensure there are no underlying issues.

9. **Try on Another Machine:**
   If possible, run `md5sum` with the same file(s) on another machine to see if it reproduces the issue. This can help determine whether the problem is specific to your system or not.

10. **Examine Core Dumps:**
    Check core dumps of the crashes for more detailed information about what went wrong.
    ```sh
    gdb /usr/bin/md5sum /path/to/corefile # Replace with actual path to core dump file.
    ```

If following these steps helps you reproduce the issue, it will be easier to understand the root cause and potentially fix or work around it. If not, it might indicate a more subtle or hardware-related problem that would require further investigation.

However, from the given data, it seems that this might be related to system configuration, performance issues with certain hardware devices, file system usage, or possibly some application behavior. Given the lack of explicit bug description, I will propose a general approach and some commands that could help in diagnosing issues related to the described systems.

1. **Check System Logs**:
   - Command: `journalctl`
     - This command can be used to check system logs which might contain information about hardware issues or any other errors.
   
2. **Hardware Diagnostics**:
   - Command: `lspci` and `lsusb`
     - These commands will list all PCI and USB devices, respectively. Checking the output against known hardware problems could help identify faulty devices.

3. **Network Interface Check**:
   - Command: `ifconfig` or `ip addr`
     - This command provides details about network interfaces which can be helpful if there are issues related to networking (like iwl3945, a wireless card).
   
4. **USB Device Check**:
   - Command: `lsusb`
     - Helps in listing all USB devices connected to the system. Useful for troubleshooting USB-related problems.
   
5. **File System Check and Usage**:
   - Command: `df -h` or `du -sh <directory>`
     - These commands show disk usage, helping diagnose issues related to file system space or performance.

6. **Hardware Monitoring**:
   - Command: `sensors`
     - This command can be used with a package like `lm-sensors` installed on the system to check hardware temperatures and fan speeds.
   
7. **Performance Monitoring**:
   - Command: `top` or `htop` (if htop is installed)
     - These commands provide real-time information about CPU, memory, and swap usage which can help in identifying performance issues.

8. **Check Specific Application Logs**:
   - Commands to check logs for specific applications might be available (e.g., `/var/log/apache2/` for Apache web server).
   
9. **Kernel Version and Configuration Check**:
   - Command: `uname -a`
     - This command shows the kernel version and other details, which can help in diagnosing issues related to kernel-specific problems.

10. **Hardware Stress Testing (if applicable)**:
    - Tool: Stress-ng
      - If the bug seems performance-related or hardware-related, stress testing could be used to reproduce any potential system instability.

Given these commands and procedures, you should try running them on a similar setup to see if you can observe the same issues. For a specific bug, more detailed information would be necessary to formulate precise steps for reproduction.

description:
Description of problem:
'date' command can no longer be used to set the hardware clock. It was never its true purpose, but it was a consequence and many system administrators rely on 'date' setting the hardware clock. From Fedora 16 that is no longer true, see bug #749516.

Please make adjustments in coreutils 'date' to reflect this change. Proposed changes:

1. Adjust date's man page to clearly state that this command sets system time, but not hardware time, and reference 'hwclock' command for the latter purpose.

2. If you consider it helpful, add a new CLI option to set the system clock and hardware clock in the same command, by internally calling hwclock in the end.

I think at least the first option would be very beneficial to implement.

Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):
coreutils-8.12-2.fc16.i686

How reproducible:
see #749516

---Problem Description---
Just installed Fedora16 Oct 17 build. Haven't done anything yet and just issued a command:

df  -k 

and then saw the following duplicated output:

[root@c57f1ju0203 ~]# df -k
Filesystem                         1K-blocks    Used Available Use% Mounted on
rootfs                              42896600 5389988  35327540  14% /
devtmpfs                             3101568       0   3101568   0% /dev
tmpfs                                3114688       0   3114688   0% /dev/shm
tmpfs                                3114688  134848   2979840   5% /run
/dev/mapper/vg_c57f1ju0203-lv_root  42896600 5389988  35327540  14% /
tmpfs                                3114688  134848   2979840   5% /run
tmpfs                                3114688       0   3114688   0% /sys/fs/cgroup
tmpfs                                3114688       0   3114688   0% /media
/dev/sda2                             495844   52221    418023  12% /boot
[root@c57f1ju0203 ~]#

There are two /run mounts shown.

Disabling sandbox does not take care of the duplication. This looks like Red Hat Bug 709351.


---uname output---
Linux c57f1ju0203.ppd.pok.ibm.com 3.1.0-0.rc9.git0.2.fc16.kh.ppc64 #1 SMP Wed Oct 12 22:41:01 UTC 2011 ppc64 ppc64 ppc64 GNU/Linux
 
Machine Type = platform        : pSeries model           : IBM,8246-L2B machine         : CHRP IBM,8246-L2B 
 
---Debugger---
A debugger is not configured
 
---Steps to Reproduce---
 1. Use VIO install the above Fedora
2. After install is done run command df -k
 
---File System Tools Component Data--- 
Userspace tool common name: df -k 
 
The userspace tool has the following bit modes: 64 

Userspace rpm: Fedora-20111017-ppc64-DVD.iso  

Userspace tool obtained from project website:  na 

Retested with Fedora Alpha and this issue still exists.

Description of problem:
No matter what I do, the system will not respect my group memberships.

During installation, I made the primary account part of the administrators group (wheel). After installation, I get error messages that I am not in the sudoers file. 

Check /etc/group, I find
wheel:x:10:justin

However, the system does not recognize this
[root@thebe ~]# groups justin
justin : justin

I have repeatedly tried `usermod -aG wheel justin` to no avail.

Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):
Name        : coreutils
Arch        : x86_64
Version     : 8.12
Release     : 2.fc16
Size        : 13 M

How reproducible:
Rebooted several times and have run updates

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Install F16 w/ Btrfs for / (not sure if Btrfs is causing part of the problem)
2. Try to sudo
3. Observe that group memberships are not respected
  
Actual results:
membership in /etc/group exists, but `groups` doesn't reflect it.

Expected results:
entries in /etc/group should match the system groups.

Additional info:

Description of problem:
The "Requires: pam" of coreutils is inadequate -- /etc/pam.d/su does an
 'include' of postlogin, but /etc/pam.d/postlogin did not exist until
 pam-1.1.3-7 .
Without /etc/pam.d/postlogin, /bin/su will fail:

  su: cannot not open session: Permission denied

with an error message in /var/log/secure:

  ... su: PAM _pam_load_conf_file: unable to open /etc/pam.d/postlogin

So the requires line in th spec file should be:
  Requires: pam >= 1.1.3-7

Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):
coreutils-8.12-2.fc16.i686
(Note: Same problem exists in util-linux-2.20-1.fc16.i686; a separate
 report has been filed against util-linux .)

This is not likely to happen on a standard spin.  And during OS install,
/etc/pam.d/postlogin is replaced by a symlink to a generated postlogin-ac .
But by examining the following, it is apparent that coreutils really does
need postlogin, and that postlogin first appeared in pam-1.1.3-7:

  $ grep postlogin /etc/pam.d/su
  $ rpm -q --changelog pam-1.1.4-4.fc16 | grep -B1 postlogin
  $ rpmls pam-1.1.4-4.fc16 | grep postlogin

Description of problem:

/bin/ls -l on an automount directory of some nature peforms the following ops on each file:

lstat("doc", {st_mode=S_IFDIR|S_ISGID|0775, st_size=4096, ...}) = 0
lgetxattr("doc", "security.selinux", "unconfined_u:object_r:default_t:s0", 255) = 35
getxattr("doc", "system.posix_acl_access", 0x0, 0) = -1 EOPNOTSUPP (Operation not supported)

and possibly also:

getxattr("/etc", "system.posix_acl_default", 0x0, 0) = -1 ENODATA (No data available)

depending on the circumstances.

The first two calls (lstat and lgetxattr) don't follow symlinks and mounts, but the second is a getxattr call which _does_ follow symlinks and mounts.  The latter can cause automount points to mount, which the former won't, at least from linux-2.6.38-rc1 onwards.

These should be consistent, and so I believe the getxattr calls should be lgetxattr calls.  Without this, the first two calls may refer to a different object to the second pair of calls.

Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):

F-13 and F-14 coreutils both show this.  coreutils-8.5-7.fc14.x86_64 is what's on my desktop.

How reproducible:

100%

Steps to Reproduce:
1. strace -e trace=lstat,getxattr,lgetxattr ls -l /media
  
Actual results:

lstat("/media", {st_mode=S_IFDIR|0755, st_size=4096, ...}) = 0
lgetxattr("/media", "security.selinux", "system_u:object_r:mnt_t:s0", 255) = 27
getxattr("/media", "system.posix_acl_access", 0x0, 0) = -1 ENODATA (No data available)
getxattr("/media", "system.posix_acl_default", 0x0, 0) = -1 ENODATA (No data available)

Expected results:

The getxattrs should be lgetxattrs.

Additional info:

This is a problem that occurs in conjunction with the acl package - that doesn't provide a way of calling lgetxattr() through it.

Description of problem:
I couldn't find "date" in the components, please file where appropriate

I can see that there is a %n for newline and a %t for tab, but I do not see a %whatever to indicate a space. I am trying to do a `date +%d%b%y %T` and it barks over the T. I can get what I want by {`date +%d%b%y` 'date +%T`}, but this seems silly to have to call date twice just to get a space inbetween. The padding doesn't help as far as I can see

Steps to Reproduce:

Error

Expected results:

Additional info:
Thanks in advance,
Paul

Description of problem:
I'd like to run a process as another user, leaving it in screen session that can be reconnected from another session. While it works without any troubles on Gentoo, it seems impossible on Fedora ...

Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):
screen-4.0.3-15.fc12

How reproducible:
always

Steps to Reproduce:
1. add two users (user1, user2)
2. log into X as user1
3. run terminal program
4. su - user2
5. screen
  
Actual results:
Cannot open your terminal '/dev/pts/6' - please check.

Expected results:
(new screen session is opened)

Additional info:
disabling selinux (setenforce 0) makes no difference
Ollama_Response:
```bash
adduser user1
adduser user2
su - user1
xterm &  # or any other terminal emulator
su - user2
screen
```

description:
So, there was the recent change:

===
* Thu Mar 19 2009 Ondrej Vasik <ovasik@redhat.com> 7.1-7
- do not ship /etc/DIR_COLORS.xterm - as many terminals
  use TERM xterm and black background as default - making
  ls color output unreadable
- shipping /etc/DIR_COLORS.lightbgcolor instead of it for
  light(white/gray) backgrounds
===

Now, I can't argue with the logic of that - TERM=xterm doesn't mean that the background is either light or dark.

*However*, as we ship Fedora we default to using white background colors in gnome-terminal and xterm. (I don't know about konsole offhand)

So it me, that if we believe that DIR_COLORS.lightbgcolor is the right set of colors with a light background, then we should make sure that people get those colors out of the box. We shouldn't ask users to:

 ln -s /etc/DIR_COLORS.lightbgcolor ~/.dircolors.xterm

to fix things to work right. (is that the preferred way to do it?)

How should this be addressed?

I just ran df -h and was suprised by the output:

In english this is ...
$ LANG=CC df -h | head -n 2
Filesystem            Size  Used Avail Use% Mounted on
rootfs                 39G   37G  1.8G  96% /

... but in German there is a % too much:
$ df -h | head -n 2
Dateisystem          Größe Benut  Verf Ben%% Eingehängt auf
rootfs                 39G   37G  1,8G  96% /

This dos not appear on "df" while it appears on "df -h"

Based on the provided log information, it seems that a core dump of `/bin/sleep` was analyzed using `gdb`. The steps to potentially reproduce the bug would include causing a core dump in `/bin/sleep`, collecting the dump file, and then analyzing it with `gdb` for debugging.

However, from the provided data, there's no information regarding why `/bin/sleep` crashed or the specific conditions that caused the crash. `/bin/sleep` is typically used to pause execution for a specified time interval and doesn't usually encounter runtime errors on its own under normal circumstances.

To attempt to reproduce this bug, one should consider the following:

1. **Recreate the Environment**: Ensure you have the same version of `/bin/sleep`, `gdb`, libraries (e.g., libc), and kernel that were present when the core dump was generated.
   
2. **Trigger Core Dumps for /bin/sleep**:
   - Make sure your system is configured to allow core dumps by setting a limit on their size: 
     ```bash
     ulimit -c unlimited
     ```
   - Attempt to cause `/bin/sleep` to crash in some way. This could be through malicious intent (e.g., injecting signals, memory corruption), but without more information about the actual issue, it's hard to suggest a specific test case.
   
3. **Analyze Core Dump**:
   - Once you have a core dump file for `/bin/sleep`, use `gdb` in a similar manner to how it was used here to analyze the crash and generate a backtrace:
     ```bash
     gdb /bin/sleep ./coredump
     ```
   - Execute commands like those mentioned in the log (`thread apply all backtrace 2048 full`, `info sharedlib`, etc.) to see if you can identify the reason for the crash.
   
Unfortunately, without additional information about the nature of the issue (e.g., what signals were being sent, what was happening around the time of the crash), it's difficult to suggest a specific test case that would reliably reproduce this bug. If there were known conditions or inputs under which `/bin/sleep` crashed in your environment, those should be used for testing.

If you have more information about the circumstances leading up to the crash (e.g., system logs, other running processes), that could also help in constructing a test case.

Ollama_Response:
Based on the given information, the described issue involves a segmentation fault when running `/bin/sleep` with a duration argument (in this case, `5m`). However, the provided backtrace and other details do not indicate any obvious issues within the sleep command itself but rather suggest that there might be something peculiar about the environment or system libraries in use.

To reproduce the bug, one should ideally try to replicate the exact setup where the fault occurred, including:

1. **OS Version:** Check the Linux distribution version and kernel version used by the user reporting the issue.
2. **Architecture:** Verify if it was a 32-bit or 64-bit system since there might be compatibility issues related to architecture.
3. **Libc Version:** Find out the exact version of glibc (GNU C Library) that is being used, as different versions can have distinct behaviors and bugs.
4. **Environment Variables:** Check if any specific environment variables were set that could affect the behavior of `/bin/sleep` or its interaction with libraries.

A simple test case to start would be:

```bash
/bin/sleep 5m
```

If this command does not trigger a segmentation fault on your system, you should attempt to match as closely as possible the conditions present in the user's environment (such as installing the exact version of glibc used by them).

However, given that `/bin/sleep` is such a fundamental and well-tested utility, it's more likely that there could be an issue with a corrupted library or other system-specific anomaly. In such cases, reproducing the issue can be challenging without access to the original environment.

If you suspect this might be due to a corrupted library or file system issue:

1. **Check for File System Errors:** Run `fsck` on the relevant filesystems.
2. **Reinstall glibc:** If possible, reinstalling the GNU C Library may resolve any corruption issues.

Without more specific details about the environment, reproducing the bug exactly might not be feasible. However, starting with running `/bin/sleep 5m` and checking for system inconsistencies is a good place to begin.

Description of problem:
When ln creates symbolic links with a target directory it fails to properly adjust paths in the created symbolic link.

Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):
coreutils-8.5-7

How reproducible:
Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1. touch file
2. mkdir t
3. ln -s -t t file  (OR ln -s file t)
4. ls -l t
5. ls -L t
  
Actual results:
4. lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root    4 2011-01-10 14:54 file -> file
5. ls: cannot access t/file: Too many levels of symbolic links

Expected results:
4. lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root    4 2011-01-10 14:54 file -> ../file
5. lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root    0 2011-01-10 14:54 file

Additional info:
Let's face it: when ln is invoked it knows exactly what the current directory is, it knows exactly where the target directory is, it knows whether the target file has been specified with a relative path, so why doesn't it correctly create a symbolic link with the proper path relative to the target directory?  Doesn't matter for hard links, but one would hope that somebody would take the time to make relative symbolic links easier to create.  Or otherwise disallow the use of the -t option when -s is used with a relative target file.  Hard to believe that this fundamental utility has existed in such a broken state for such a long time.

More additional info:
The use of the terminology "target directory" is potentially confusing because the word "target" is also used in the context of "target of the symbolic link".  It is in fact the output or temporary current directory and would be better named as that (ie. -c, --current-directory). Fortunately the -c option is free for use.
Ollama_Response:
```bash
touch file
mkdir t
ln -s -t t file
ls -l t
ls -L t
```

description:
Description of problem:
When dd reads from a pipe it produces random results

Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):
coreutils-6.9-9

How reproducible:
Always

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Find a large file, say 10MB
2. cat largefile | dd ibs=100000 count=2 >output1
3. repeat 2) several times recording size of output1
4. dd if=largefile | dd ibs=100000 count=2 >output2
5. repeat 4) several times recording size of output2
  
Actual results:
The size of output will vary.
2. Various sizes such as 65536,139264,143360.
5. Various sizes such as 6144,7168,6656

Expected results:
size should always be 200000, and never anything else

Additional info:
The apparent block size of a pipe "device" should be transparent.
But in any case, when using ibs we are instructing dd what the input block size
is!  So dd should obey our instructions, and not use other block size.
Interesting to note that a conceptually simple program like dd has been so
hacked around since v5.2 that it is a wonder it still works at all.
Ollama_Response:
```bash
cat largefile | dd ibs=100000 count=2 >output1
dd if=largefile | dd ibs=100000 count=2 >output2
```

Additional info:

I have attached a .c file which is intended to be part of a gedit plugin, but functions as a standalone binary.

When compiled, and executed via su on Fedora 13 (x86_64, although, I doubt arch matters), this is the result:

[spot@f13 ~]$ touch /tmp/foo
[spot@f13 ~]$ su - --command="/home/spot/gedit-beesu-plugin gedit-beesu-plugin /usr/bin/gedit gedit /tmp/foo"
Password:

About to spawn the daemon().
Filling Commandline
About to execvp(/usr/bin/gedit, gedit (null))

*** gedit opens, as root, in the X session (GNOME) ***

Now, when I try to do the same thing on Fedora 14 (x86_64), it fails:
[spot@pterodactyl ~]$ su - --command="/home/spot/gedit-beesu-plugin gedit-beesu-plugin /usr/bin/gedit gedit /tmp/foo"
Password: 
Entering main.
Checking for the lockfile /tmp/foo...
...found it!
About to unlink the lockfile.
About to spawn the daemon().
Filling Commandline
About to execvp(/usr/bin/gedit, gedit (null))
[spot@pterodactyl ~]$ No protocol specified

(gedit:1808): Gtk-WARNING **: cannot open display: :0.0

******
Now, the env values from both systems show that XAUTHORITY and DISPLAY are surviving through su. There is no change if -p is passed to su (it works on F13, it does not work on F14).

sudo works properly on both systems, where my user is in sudoers with ALL=(ALL)	ALL (invocation: sudo -- /home/spot/gedit-beesu-plugin gedit-beesu-plugin /usr/bin/gedit gedit /tmp/foo), which leads me to believe the bug is in su.

description:
Description of problem:

runuser is supposed to be su without pam.

# runuser dwalsh
runuser: incorrect password

abrt version: 1.1.13
architecture: x86_64
Attached file: backtrace
cmdline: sort --version
component: coreutils
crash_function: raise
executable: /bin/sort
kernel: 2.6.34.7-61.fc13.x86_64
package: coreutils-8.4-9.fc13
rating: 4
reason: Process /bin/sort was killed by signal 6 (SIGABRT)
release: Fedora release 13 (Goddard)
time: 1288387960
uid: 500

comment
-----
sort from coreutils just crashes and does not work at all. Output is

sort: sort.c:1306: inittables_mb: Assertion `mblength != (size_t)-1 && mblength != (size_t)-2' failed.
Aborted (core dumped)

I'm using coreutils-8.4.9.fc13 on an updated F13 system (x86_64).
I have also tried to rebuild coreutils-8.5-5.fc14.1.src.rpm for F13, but the result is the same.

How to reproduce
-----
1. run "sort" in any way (like "sort --version")

upstream coreutils' su doesn't support PAM. Distributions add
support for PAM as patch. RedHat and SUSE's patches apparently share
a common ancestor but diverged over time. This is another attempt to
agree on a common patch that could potentially be sent upstream.
The previous attempt failed due to inactivity, see bug 240117.
Here's a cleaned up version of the previous patch. I've removed the getdef features and the setting of the default path which are unrelated to the pam feature.
Compared to the current patch in Fedora this one
- does not require a tty. Requiring a tty doesn't make sense to me and could be enforced via PAM module if really needed.
- calls pam_setcred() after initgroups() to allow PAM modules change supplementary groups
- does not handle DISPLAY and XAUTHORITY. pam_xauth does that for us.

Description of problem:
cp --no-dereference --preserve=all  or cp -Pp
preserves alright the attributes of a file, but not those of
a symlink. The copy of the symlink gets timestamped with the
current time.

Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):
bash version 3.2 Release 9.fc5.1, but the cp used does not seem
to be a bash builtin. Not sure what package includes cp.  

How reproducible:
always

Steps to Reproduce:
1. create a tests directory, cd tests
   cat > file1
   contents of file 1
   ^C
   ln -s file1 symlink1
   ls -l
    .... wait 2 minutes here ....
   cp -Pp file1 file1c
   cp -Pp symlink1 symlink1c
   ls -l

2. observe that the date/time of file1 and file1c are identical,
   while those of symlink1 symlink1c are not.
  
Actual results:
different timestamps in source and target symlinks

Expected results:
same timestamp in source and target symlinks


Additional info:
None
Ollama_Response:
```bash
mkdir tests && cd tests
echo "contents of file 1" > file1
ln -s file1 symlink1
ls -l
sleep 120
cp -Pp file1 file1c
cp -Pp symlink1 symlink1c
ls -l
```

Description of problem:
/sbin/mount.tmpfs will emit error messages at boot time, and fails to turn
off restricted mode, if two conditions are met:
    1. A tmpfs filesystem is used (listed in /etc/fstab).
    2. /usr is a separate filesystem, mounted after a tmpfs filesystem.
The problem is simply that /sbin/mount.tmpfs uses 'id', which is in
/usr/bin/id, and hence not yet available.

Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):
coreutils-8.4-8.fc13.i686
(The error message is emitted by /sbin/mount.tmpfs, but the easy fix is
to coreutils; see "Additional info" below.)

How reproducible:
100%

Steps to Reproduce:
Prerequisites:
  A tmpfs filesystem in /etc/fstab, e.g.:
      tmpfs  /tmp  tmpfs  defaults  0 0
  A separate /usr filesystem, listed after tmpfs in /etc/fstab .
Then boot (single-user will do).

Actual results:
On the system console (also in /var/log/boot.log):
  Mounting local filesystems:  /sbin/mount.tmpfs: line 22: id: command not found
  /sbin/mount.tmpfs: line 23: id: command not found
  /sbin/mount.tmpfs: line 25: [: -eq: unary operator expected

Expected results:
No error messages after "Mounting local filesystems".

Additional info:
Two possibilities to fix:
1. Change the location of 'id' from /usr/bin/id to /bin/id, in the coreutils
   package.
2. Make all the 'id' code in /sbin/mount.tmpfs be conditional on
   'type -t id >/dev/null', and if that fails, assume it's boot time, and
   set restricted=0 .  (No, I don't like it either.)

The Danish translation of coreutils shipped with Fedora 13 has an encoding-related error which causes the three special Danish letters (æøå) to be displayed incorrectly.  The problem has been fixed upstream, but the error is still present in Fedora 13.

Please get the new translations and issue an update to the package.

Description of problem:
who does not take group owner of tty into account when determining users'
message status

Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable):
coreutils-6.9-17.fc8

[root@fc8d ~]# ls -l /dev/pts*
total 0
crw--w---- 1 root  root 136, 0 Jul  7 12:37 0
crw--w---- 1 user_a tty  136, 1 Jul  7 12:37 1
crw--w---- 1 root  tty  136, 2 Jul  7 12:42 2

[root@fc8d ~]# who -wu
user_a    + pts/0        Jul  7 11:43 00:05       27269 (hostname.domain)
user_a    + pts/1        Jul  7 12:31 00:05       15316 (hostname.domain)
root     + pts/2        Jul  7 12:32   .         15345 (hostname.domain)

Actually, user "user_a" on tty /dev/pts/0 has "mesg n" (because of tty group: root).
Bug does occur when logged through gdm.

"who" should check getgrnam("tty") gr_gid against stat("/dev/...") s_gid or
should be setgid tty and check term gid against getegid().

Description of problem:
/bin/mount.crypt from pam_mount uses readlink. Since it might be called to umount partitions after /usr is umounted, it will fail because it cannot access readlink. Therefore please move readlink from /usr/bin to /bin. It might be a good idea to add a symlink afterwards from /usr/bin/readlink to ../../bin/readlink to avoid problems with hardcoded paths.
